awd_titl_txt: CHAI: Improving the Resiliency and Security of the Cyber-Infrastructure at SWC
awd_abstract_narration:
A goal of the Tribal Colleges and Universities Program (TCUP) is to increase the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) instructional and research capacities of specific institutions of higher education that serve the Nation's indigenous students. Expanding the instructional, research, and development capacity at these institutions expands the opportunities for students to pursue challenging, rewarding careers in STEM fields, provides for research studies in areas that may be locally relevant, and encourages a faculty community to look beyond the traditional classroom for intellectual and professional growth. This project aligns directly with that goal by strengthening the STEM cyberinfrastructure at Sisseton Wahpeton College (SWC) for instructional and research activities. The project aims to enhance cyberinfrastructure and cybersecurity necessary to facilitate development of the institution in STEM fields and for the protection of sensitive data. 

The project seeks to upgrade specific STEM IT resources at the institution to improve the resiliency and security of STEM operations, data management, teaching, and research enterprises. Improvements to SWC’s network and cybersecurity seeks to advance the college’s ability to implement future data management plans and expand remote access for virtual synchronous instruction. The activities for developing STEM cyberinfrastructure will directly support current and future projects. Students will benefit from increased access to online resources and virtual courses. STEM research activities in language, culture, and natural resources will be aided and enabled by advances in cyberinfrastructure at the institution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The objective of the project proposed to the National Science Foundation’s TCUP CHAI strand was to strengthen the resiliency and security of the cyberinfrastructure at Sisseton Wahpeton College (SWC). As a small tribal college located in northeastern South Dakota, SWC faces numerous issues to provide the cyberinfrastructure required to offer high quality STEM education to our students. While these challenges were intensified by the pandemic and when the college received approval to offer our first baccalaureate degree program, a B.S. in Behavioral Science, the core problems existed prior to these events.

 

Due to the college’s location, SWC experiences frequent power outages and rolling brownouts which disrupt both services and damages sensitive systems such as blade servers and SANs. While the college has large generators to mitigate power loss caused by blizzards and other storms, these units take time to begin generating electricity and do little to address low-power or surges in the flow of electricity. This project increased the college’s critical UPS capacity and led its transition to more efficient lithium batteries which have a significantly longer service life.

 

First the pandemic, then the offering of baccalaureate programs led to an increased demand for hybrid and distance education options by our students. The HyFlex model, which has been highly successful, tested the capacity of the college’s cyberinfrastructure resources both internally and externally. New instructional technologies were added to classrooms to facilitate the simultaneous delivery of courses to students both on and off site. This project provided the resources to upgrade the network backbone to 10Gb across campus which also supports faster access to network storage and lessens the time needed to complete critical backups of data.

 

This project provided significant support towards strengthening the college’s cybersecurity efforts. These enhancements included expanding the use of multifactor identification, upgrading to a more robust malware/antivirus protection package, and adding network edge security. Given the expanding number of bad-actors and threats, cybersecurity concerns were a limiting factor to the growth of our STEM programs. As a small institution, SWC is reliant on having adjunct professors instruct specific STEM courses and to provide more options to offer courses in ways to meet our primarily non-traditional students’ needs.

 


Last Modified: 11/07/2023
Modified by: Scott Morgan
